Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
Notaries will be paid X coins when they make a notarisation as long as it has the required inputs (a notary cannot sign twice) and is an OP_RETURN containing a valid block height and hash. 
It no longer matters what order notarizations occur. Because if reorgs happen, some notarizations that create a valid checkpoint dont actaully exist in the chain at all. Which is not something I thaught was possible when I started on this.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Always learning... Its not al bad, there were amny imporvments to the overall code and how it works.. I dint actually ahve to remove a lot. Took about an hour.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Basically removing the payment's ability to vary with the number of blocks and we now assume that notarization frequncy is always 5. If min sigs of notaries decide to lower freq, they will get paid mroe. We just have to trust them on this. Its still better than having 0 incentive to notarize. 游땎

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: `CFEKULTRADEAD` It shall be 游땏

Author: blackjok3r#3181
blackjok3r#3181
Content:
With eras verified to wirk in the last test. And the new validation. It should be no longer possible to reorg notarzations out of the chain to cause damage. 
It limits 1 notarisationper block, valid (in order) or not... Then will create a coinbase to pay notaries who made this notarization. In case of reorg attack it could take some time to clear all the notarizations out of the back log, but there is simply no otherway to let this happen, and have the chain never fork.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Reorg attack stops notarizations from working, there is NOTHING we can do to fix this. If you get 100% attacked your 100% attacked sadly.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @blackjok3r if you cant 100% fully understand all the possible code paths, then 100% guaranteed by Murphys Law that at the worst time whatever part you didnt understand will cause a catastrophic failure. 99% isnt good enough

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also, "if it works, dont fix it" is very important advice

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you need to weigh the risk of an attack and the worst case outcome of such an attack against the 100% cost of complications. 100% defense is impossible. period. There will always be a way to attack , so the trick is to balance how much complexity is used to defend against the attacks

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: removing validation was the onlyt way forward here

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for instance, I now see many attempts at defending against 51% that are not dPoW, probably a combination of NIH syndrome. But most all of these "alternatives" have some complex logic with very hard to understand consequences. Some have easy to see exploits.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW is actually very very simple as it just extends the already existing checkpoints checking with a notarization and now it also specifically prevents reorg of the notarized block. That is about as simple of a change as it can be to satoshi consensus, yet it took 2 years! to stabilize it

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Ther is no problem with dpow... trhe problem is that a miner can reorg all the chakpoints out of the chain... and if you use those checkpoints for a consesnus thing such as a block reward, they are no longer valid when you sync it

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: its ok... I worked out hwo to get around this issue... dont use a checkpoint for a consensus rule
